question: Question_05
statement:
Full-Solution Problems. Justify your answers and show all your work.
Simplification of answers is not required.

The vertical cross-sections of a bathtub perpendicular to its long axis
have the shape shown below. They are squares of side length 50cm
surmounting a semicircle. Assuming the tub is full of water, find the
hydrostatic force on one of its vertical ends (which also has the shape
below). For the density of water, use the value 1000
kg/m\textsuperscript{3} and for the acceleration due to gravity, use the
value 9.8 m/s\textsuperscript{2}.

\begin{figure}[htbp]
\centering
\includegraphics[width=.5\textwidth]{MATH101Apr2006Q5Statement.jpeg}
\caption{MATH101Apr2006Q5Statement.jpeg}
\end{figure}
sols:
Start by placing a coordinate system on your picture with 0 on top. We
break the problem up into two parts. First, we take care of the square.

Choose a sample point $\displaystyle x_{i}^{*}$ somewhere between 0 and
50 on your picture. Draw the horizontal line across at this point. A
picture is included below.

\begin{figure}[htbp]
\centering
\includegraphics[width=.5\textwidth]{Math101042006Q5pt1.jpg}
\caption{Math101042006Q5pt1.jpg}
\end{figure}

The area of this horizontal strip is given by

$\displaystyle A_{i} = 50\Delta x$.

The pressure on this strip is given by

$\displaystyle P_{i} = \rho g x_{i}^{*}$.

where $\displaystyle \rho = 1000$ is the density of water and
$\displaystyle g = 9.8$ is the acceleration due to gravity. Thus, the
force on this strip is

$\displaystyle F_{i} = P_{i}A_{i} = 50\rho g x_{i}^{*} \Delta x$.

The total force is

$\displaystyle F_{sq} = \lim_{n \to \infty}\sum_{i=1}^{n}F_{i} =  \lim_{n \to \infty}\sum_{i=1}^{n}50\rho g x_{i}^{*} \Delta x$.

This can be expressed as the following integral

$\displaystyle F_{sq} = \int_{0}^{50}50\rho g x \, dx$

Now we compute the force on the semicircle and add it to this force to
get the total force. To make the notation easier, I will reuse some of
the letters from above.

Choose a sample point $\displaystyle x_{i}^{*}$ somewhere between 50 and
75 on your picture. Draw the horizontal line across at this point. A
picture is included below.

\begin{figure}[htbp]
\centering
\includegraphics[width=.5\textwidth]{Math101042006Q5pt3.jpg}
\caption{Math101042006Q5pt3.jpg}
\end{figure}

To compute the length of the horizontal line, draw the radius as shown
in the picture. Then the Pythagorean theorem tells us that the length
across is double $\displaystyle \sqrt{25^{2} - (x_{i}^{*}-50)^{2}}$.
Thus, the area of this strip is given by

$\displaystyle A_{i} = 2\sqrt{25^{2} - (x_{i}^{*}-50)^{2}}\Delta x$.

The pressure on this strip is given by

$\displaystyle P_{i} = \rho g x_{i}^{*}$.

Thus, the force on this strip is

$\displaystyle F_{i} = P_{i}A_{i} = 2\sqrt{25^{2} - (x_{i}^{*}-50)^{2}}\rho g x_{i}^{*} \Delta x$.

The total force is

$\displaystyle F_{circ} = \lim_{n \to \infty}\sum_{i=1}^{n}F_{i} =  \lim_{n \to \infty}\sum_{i=1}^{n}2\sqrt{25^{2} - (x_{i}^{*}-50)^{2}}\rho g x_{i}^{*} \Delta x$.

This can be expressed as the following integral

$\displaystyle F_{circ} = \int_{50}^{75}2\sqrt{25^{2} - (x-50)^{2}}\rho g x \, dx$

Adding the two integrals together, we get

\begin{align*}
F_{tot} &= F_{sq} + F_{circ} \\
&= \int_{0}^{50}50\rho g x + \int_{50}^{75}2\sqrt{25^{2} - (x-50)^{2}}\rho g x \, dx \\
&= \frac{50\rho g x^{2}}{2} \bigg|_{0}^{50} + \int_{0}^{25}2\sqrt{25^{2} - x^{2}}\rho g (x+50) \, dx\\
&= 25\rho g (50)^{2} + \int_{0}^{25}2\sqrt{25^{2} - x^{2}}\rho g x \, dx + \int_{0}^{25}100\sqrt{25^{2} - x^{2}}\rho g \, dx\\
\end{align*}

The last integral can be recognized as the {[}scaled{]} area of a
quarter circle of a circle with radius 25. The first integral we can let
$\displaystyle u = 25^{2} - x^{2}$. When \emph{x} = 0, then \emph{u}=
625 and when \emph{x} = 25 then \emph{u}=0 and
$\displaystyle du = -2xdx$. Hence,

\begin{align*}
F_{tot} &= 25\rho g (50)^{2} - \int_{625}^{0}\sqrt{u}\rho g \, du + 100\rho g \frac{\pi(25)^{2}}{4}\\
&= 25\rho g (50)^{2} + \int_{0}^{625}\sqrt{u}\rho g \, du + 25\rho g \pi(25)^{2}\\
&= 25\rho g (50)^{2} + \frac{2u^{3/2}\rho g}{3} \bigg|_{0}^{625} + \rho g \pi(25)^{3}\\
&= 25\rho g (50)^{2} + \frac{2(25)^{3}\rho g}{3} + \rho g \pi(25)^{3}\\
\end{align*}

which is our final answer.
hints:
It helps to break this problem up into two shapes and deal with the
force on each shape. Put a coordinate system on this figure so that 0 is
on top. Then choose a sample point first only in the square then next
only in the semicircle.

For the semicircle, at a sample point, draw a horizontal line and
connect a radius from the centre of the semicircle to the intersection
point with the horizontal line and the semicircle. Then use Pythagorean
theorem to determine lengths. A picture is included in the solution and
might make this hint clearer.

Recall that the hydrostatic pressure at a depth h measured from the top
of a surface is given by,

\[\displaystyle P=\rho{g}h\]

where $\displaystyle  \rho$ is the density of the substance exerting the
force (water in this case) and $\displaystyle  g$ is the acceleration
due to gravity.
